verb.description: Suspend or be suspended from above with the lower part dangling free.
examples: that's where people are supposed to hang their wash
a chain hanging freely over two pegs

verb.description: Kill (someone) by tying a rope attached from above around the neck and removing the support from beneath (used as a form of capital punishment)
examples: she hanged herself in her cell
a haze of smoke hung below the ceiling

verb.description: Come or cause to come unexpectedly to a state in which no further operations can be carried out.
Spend time relaxing or enjoying oneself.
examples: I guess I wasn't cool enough to hang with them anymore
we'll be walking along just hanging, chilling

verb.description: Deliver (a breaking pitch) that does not change direction as intended.
(of a juror) prevent (a jury) from reaching a verdict by a dissenting vote.

examples: the bullish hang of his head

phrases: it's quite simple when you get the hang of it
This tool is a little tricky to get the hang of, but works well once you know what you are doing.
I don't know if I've quite got the hang of eating properly.
This felt a little awkward at first, but I eventually got the hang of it.
He has learned to double-click, and is getting the hang of drag-and-drop.
undercover officers spent most of their time hanging around bars
hang about, you see what it says here?
he never hangs around with that gang
there's this guy named Johnnie who I hang round with
Stephen hung back for fear of being seen
origin: Old English hangian (intransitive verb), of West Germanic origin, related to Dutch and German hangen, reinforced by the Old Norse transitive verb hanga.
